Description.val:
The MQ-8 Vertical Take-Off and Landing Tactical Unmanned Aerial Vehicle (popular name "Fire Scout") provides real-time and non-real-time Intelligence, Surveillance and Reconnaissance data to tactical users without the use of manned aircraft or reliance on limited joint theater or national assets. This line item funds improvements via engineering change orders, correction of deficiencies, obsolescence and safety.  This includes items such as modernization, modification of payloads/mission systems/Ground Control System (GCS), and retrofit of systems/avionics.  Currently, the program has delivered 21 MQ-8B aircraft.  A total of 23 MQ-8B aircraft, 15 MQ-8C aircraft, and 25 ground control stations will deliver by 2015.  This is a FY2015 new start that aligns to the MQ-8 Initial Operational Capability in 2014. 

The MQ-8 Fire Scout system is comprised of air vehicles, payloads (electro-optical/infra-red/laser designator-range finder, AIS, communications relay, radar, weapons and other special payloads), GCS (with Tactical Control System and Tactical Common Data Link integrated for interoperability), UAV Common Automatic Recovery System (UCARS) for automatic take-off and landings, and associated spares and support equipment.

Justification.val: This line item funds improvements via engineering change orders, correction of deficiencies, obsolescence and safety. This includes correction of deficiencies found during operational use and deployments, improvements for maintainability and reliability, safety corrections, radar/weapons/other special payloads, emerging requirements, and concurrency in MQ-8 development and production.

ModificationTitle.val: MQ-8 Correction of Deficiences and Modernization (OSIP 021-14)

Description.val:
This Operational, Safety and Improvement Program (OSIP) will improve capability to operate in hot temperature environments, improve system performance, reliability and maintainability of sensors, avionics and airframe components, and provide broader sensors for Intelligence, Surveillance, & Reconnaissance (ISR) collection for both Navy and urgent operational requirements. Weather mods will be Depot Level, performed at Fleet Readiness Centers (FRCs). These are structural modifications to access panels (vents added), modification of belly panel (depot removal and modification), installation of vent and access door on tailboom, structural modification of inside of sponson to install larger cooling fan. 

This OSIP will also correct deficiencies resulting from obsolescence and diminishing manufacturing sources. These components include, but are not limited to, the Vehicle Management Computer, Payloads Interface Unit, the Ground Control Station's Real Time Processor, ARC-210 Radios, and the Digital Control Processor.

This OSIP will also support Payload mods which will be Depot level, performed at FRCs. Structural and wiring modifications for mounting and wiring provisions of additional payloads. Installation of the payloads themselves would be done at the O-level based on mission requirements. 

This OSIP supports MQ-8B, MQ-8C aircraft systems, Ground Control Station, UAV Common Automated Recovery System, Tactical Control Data Link, and payloads. Aircraft will be modified in FY15 to support obsolescence/reliability corrections, radar/weapons/other payloads, ice detection and landing system improvements, and hot weather modifications. A Capability Production Document, Joint Requirements Oversight Council Memorandum 004-99, and a Joint Rapid Acquisition Cell Memorandum AF-0002 apply.

DEVELOPMENT STATUS/MAJOR DEVELOPMENT MILESTONES: 
MQ-8 Initial Operational Capability is FY14.  Ongoing MQ-8B deployments have occurred since FY10 to support the ISR Task Force, Joint Urgent Operational Need, and Urgent Operational Need requirements.  The first MQ-8C deployment providing Rapid Deployment Capabilities is available for tasking as early as FY15.
